entry.title: Purchasing Planning Monitor for Collective Evaluation of MRP Planning Results
entry.content:
Summary

This blog post describes how to build a planning monitoring tool to evaluate and manage the MRP results for multiple materials. This tool can show per material the historical consumption data – consumption-based planning – together with the stocks and requirements information – material requirements planning –, and the corresponding MRP created receipt elements to cover the shortages.

The target audience for this blog post will be consulting people, project team members, key users, and subject matter experts who are interested on the visualization of the MRP results.

 

Introduction

A typical customer requirement is to visualize the result of the MRP run for several materials in a report format, that is, they want MD04 for every material on a plant in a single screen. The purpose is to have an easy and fast way of identification of critical materials where the planner needs to take an action, and then being able to select the specific material and drill down into the stock, requirements and planning elements details. There is not a standard report available that would show a detailed display of stock/requirements list for multiple materials.

A collective MRP results view is normally something very difficult to build, as companies have thousands of materials per plant with different business cases concerning procurement types, planning strategies, production types, origin of the requirements, etc… Furthermore, the target information to be displayed is different depending on the user role:

  • As a production supervisor, buyer, sales executive or MRP controller, you want to access information on the stock/requirements situation of the material, and then gain an overview of the development of stock and requirements in the coming weeks.
  • As a production supervisor, you want to gain an overview of the MRP elements for in-house production (planned orders, production orders, dependent reservations) or of the MRP elements for a particular production line.
  • As a buyer, you want to check which purchase orders and purchase requisitions exist for a material for a particular vendor.
  • As a sales executive, you are only interested in the current sales orders for a particular customer for a material.
  • As an MRP controller, you are interested in available quantities based on sales orders that have actually been received and not on the basis of the planned independent requirements. You therefore want the planned independent requirements to be displayed, but do not want to change the available quantity if sales order exists.
  • As an MRP controller, you want to be informed about the requirements of bulk materials or materials that are planned using consumption-based planning, to check whether these requirements occur continually.

Another issue to consider is the requirement of some customers to manage historical consumption data together with the requirements information, thus allowing them to compare future needs with past consumptions on the same periods in the same single screen.

Therefore, having all these requirements and conditions in mind, we may think that building a collective tool to evaluate and manage the MRP results for multiple materials becomes a great challenge. This blog explains how this collective planning tool can be built for isolated and specific planning scenarios.

 

Evaluating the Planning Run on SAP S/4HANA

For Classic MRP, the available tools for checking the planning results are the following:

  • Stock/Requirements List
  • MRP List
  • Evaluation of the Planning Situation
  • Evaluation of the Planning Result
  • Planning Table for repetitive manufacturing

During the planning run, the system analyzes the requirements that exist for the planned materials and creates procurement or manufacturing elements to cover these requirements. The evaluations on these tools show all receipt and issue elements for a material in tabular form and enable you to gain a quick overview of the stock/requirements situation for the material as well as to branch into the processing function for the MRP elements for this material.

In the stock/requirements list, the most up-to-date stock and requirements situation is displayed. Changes that are made after the planning date are displayed directly, so the list is dynamic. The MRP list always displays the stock/requirements situation at the time of the last planning run. Changes that are made after the planning date are not taken into consideration, so the list is static.

The planning situation takes all changes in stock, receipts and issues that occur between planning runs into account (as in the stock/requirements list). The planning result displays the result of the last planning run (as in the MRP list). The main difference is that you set up a special evaluation layout for the formatting of the data in the planning result and planning situation. This layout defines which receipt and issue elements are displayed at which level of aggregation.

In SAP S/4HANA, the MRP Live is used, and we also have the MRP Cockpit Fiori Apps and the MPR Situation Handling. MRP Lists are gone with MRP Live due to the considerable performance improvement. The several available MRP Cockpit Fiori Apps display an overview of materials with possible stock shortages, and you can also drill down into a specific material to see the stock/requirements situation.

The new Fiori Apps for MRP evaluation are more visually appealing, and they contain features only available in Fiori, such as Demand-Driven MRP (DDMRP) and Predictive MRP (pMRP). Moreover, they are also supported in mobile devices.

On below table you can find a summary of the abovementioned MRP transactions or Fiori Apps:

Application

Description

Transaction MD04        

Display Individual Stock/Requirements Situation

Transaction MD07

Display Collective Stock/Requirements Situation

Transaction MD05

Individual Display of MRP List

Transaction MD06

Collective Display of MRP List

Transaction MD44

Planning Situation

Transaction MD47

Collective Display for Planning Situation

Transaction MD45

Planning Result

Transaction MD46

Collective Display for Planning Result

Transaction MD48

Multi-Plant Planning Situation

Fiori App F0251A

Manage Material Coverage

Fiori App F2101A

Monitor Material Coverage

 

Customer Requirement for a Collective Evaluation of the MRP Planning Results

Customer business case was a small-sized food company with mainly a mass production environment using discrete manufacturing. Main finished products were fresh products sent to retailers to be sold on the supermarket’s shelf. Therefore, demand was seasonal but also with a special focus on daily consumption pattern.  The customer was interested on running the MRP with requirements based on forecast demand, but also considering the historical consumption of the last four weeks per day, to have the whole picture.

Since it was just a small company, there were only two main MRP responsible for the whole of the planning process and availability control for purchasing products, intermediate production and final product production. The two main areas of responsibility were MPS products, covering the final products to sale, and MRP products, covering the products for purchasing and intermediate production. On this blog we will focus on the MRP products.

The customer used a make-to-stock production (goods sold from stock) because of the following reasons:

  • The materials were produced independently of the sales orders.
  • The materials were not assigned to specific sales orders (not segregated).
  • Costs was required to be tracked at material level, and not at sales order level.

The main objective was to quickly provide the clients with goods from the stock. The main constraint was that real sales orders were often received from clients only for one day, and normally with just one day in advance or even the same day. Therefore, customer needed to produce goods without having the sales orders, as expecting the clients demand in future.

On this make-to-stock scenario, to avoid unreasonably high stock levels, a production plan is created in advance, and then you decide whether sales orders exceeding your plan are to affect production or not. Receiving sales orders as early as possible (using scheduling agreements, for example) also contributes to minimize high stock levels, but it was unrealistic on this customer, so a smooth demand forecast was key.

The production was determined by a production plan based on demand forecast (demand management), and only sales orders for first day exceeding the plan directly influenced production. If available, sales order information for subsequent days was required to be displayed for information purposes only (as normally info was uncompleted), but forecast was the demand driver except for the first day. Therefore, planning strategy used was net requirements planning on plant level (strategy 10), which allows to smooth the demand program.

Another very important considerations of the customer for achieving an effective materials planning were the following:

  • Customer wanted to expedite material planning with a more detailed collective material overview than the one provided by standard SAP S/4HANA MRP apps.
  • Customer requested to analyze materials on a dynamic periodic basis, mainly daily, but also weekly and monthly. The operative planning is usually managed by day, meanwhile medium-term planning should be managed by week/month.
  • Customer requested a calculation of stock coverage for every period displayed.
  • Customer worked with two planning modes: the real-time mode, like MD04 with the most up-to-date stock and requirements situation, and the fix-photo mode, similar to MD05 (MRP-List) with a snapshot at the beginning of the day with the situation of initial stock, requirements and receipts.
  • Customer did not plan materials at MRP areas level.
  • Customer needed a more flexible material selection by using the typical grouping fields available on material master.
  • Customer needed a flexible visualization of quantities in several units of measure.

Customer requirement for MRP monitoring was to build a new collective tool to evaluate and manage the MRP results for multiple materials. On this tool, future requirements would be displayed together with historical data, thus allowing the customer to compare future needs with past consumptions on the same period. Initial stock and final stock situation for every period based on total requirements and receipts were also required to be displayed.

Final decision was to create two similar planning monitoring tools: one focused on MPS products, the MPS Production Planning Monitor, and other focused on MRP products, the MRP Purchasing Planning Monitor. On this blog we will focus on the MRP Purchasing Planning Monitor, which is described in detail down below.

Figure 1: Material Scope for MRP Live run with MPS/MRP materials.

 

Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP

The Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP was intended for displaying the stock/requirements/receipts situation for a particular or a series of materials, from the point of view of purchasing or intermediate production. The prerequisite was the MRP Live (operative production plan MPS & MRP) previously executed for the corresponding plant, and this was automatically done daily at night by a background job.

The evaluations on this Monitor display all receipt and issue elements for the materials in the form of a table and enable the planner to gain a quick overview of the stock/requirements/receipts situation for the material, as well as to branch into the detail list for the different MRP elements for this material. After a normal MPS&MRP run, the planner checks the stock/requirements/receipts situation for the materials, make necessary changes and ensures the availability of the materials for the next days, by creating purchase or production orders. The tool also allowed working by fixing the planning elements either purchase requisitions or planned orders, but customer planners used to directly create the purchase or production orders.

As planners of this customer were old-school heavy users of SAP systems, this Monitor was developed in form of ALV list by using the BAPI_MATERIAL_STOCK_REQ_LIST function.

 

Selection Screen for Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP

The selection screen of the new Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool is displayed on below image (Figure 2):

Figure 2: Selection Screen of the Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool.

 

The period to be considered must be selected using the fields “Date From” and “Date To”. One week is proposed by default.

Requirements/receipts can be shown by day, by week or by month: this is managed by field “Period Type”. The operative planning (short-term planning) is usually managed by day, while medium-term planning should be managed by week/month.

The materials to be shown can be selected by material type, material group, MRP controller and/or material code.

The default “Planning Mode” is executed by using the fix photo of the initial stock (“Planning Fix-Photo”). Using this mode the entire requirements of the day and the entire purchase orders are shown. The other mode is the online planning which uses the current available stock on real-time (“Planning Real-Time”). Using this other mode only the pending requirements of the day and the pending purchase orders are shown.

The quantities shown can be displayed on any unit of measure available in the materials. The monitor allows to select the base unit of measure of the material, the kilograms or an alternative unit of measure to be entered by the user.

The total percentage of loss of the materials can be displayed as scrap (internal SAP), but also as drop or yield. This is just a percentage related to food processing to be considered by the planner during the evaluation process.

The calculation of stock coverage on periods can be dynamically changed to consider or not the “-Expired stock” and the “+Purchases”.

Finally, consumption history can be shown together with MRP data, for 1 period only or for 4 periods.

 

Output List for Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP

An example of the output list of the new Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool is displayed on below image (Figure 3):

Figure 3: Output List of the Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool.

 

This new monitoring tool allows to display at the same time the following data:

  • MRP planning results over sales & forecast (future).
  • Consumption history (past).

The MRP evaluation on this Monitor displays all receipt and issue elements for every material in the form of a table and enable the planner to gain a quick overview of the stock/requirements/receipts situation for the material. Moreover, for every period the historical consumption for the material is shown for the fourth previous periods, and also the average. This allows the planner to compare future needs with past consumptions on the same period.

Requirements are shown in negative - quantity and receipts in positive + quantity, in order to ease the coverage understanding. A colour code red-yellow-green is used on field “Stock Final” to easily identify stock breaks.

This new tool also allows to branch into the detail list for the different MRP elements shown for the material, as well as for the available stock (initial), just with a double click on the corresponding cell.

The explanation of the meaning of the different columns of the new Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool is summarized on below image (Figure 4):

Figure 4: Explanation of the Columns of the Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool.

 

Displaying Options for Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP

Requirements and receipts can be shown by day, by week or by month: this is managed by field “Period Type” on the selection screen. The operative planning is usually managed by day, while medium-term planning is managed by week/month.

 

Figure 5: Output List of the Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool with Period Type by Week.

Figure 6: Output List of the Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool with Period Type by Month.

 

The monitor has an option for avoiding displaying empty lines, thus planner being able to only focus on periods containing data.

Figure 7: Output List of the Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool without empty lines.

 

The monitor also allows to branch into the detail list for the different MRP elements shown for the material, as well as for the available stock (initial), just with a double click on the corresponding cell. The available screens for the data details are the following:

  • With double-click on the initial stock cell of the first period (current period), you navigate to detail stock list.
  • With double-click on any requirements cell, you navigate to detail requirements list.
  • With double-click on any receipts cell, you navigate to detail receipts list.
  • With double-click on any consumption cell, you navigate to detail historical consumption list.

Figure 8: Detail Stock List when double-clicking on the initial stock cell of the first period

Figure 9: Detail Requirements List when double-clicking on any requirement cell

Figure 10: Detail Receipts List with Purchase Orders when double-clicking on any receipt cell (external procurement material)

Figure 11: Detail Receipts List with Production Orders when double-clicking on any receipt cell (internal procurement material)

Figure 12: Detail Historical Consumption List when double-clicking on any consumption cell 13

 

For dummy materials (non-stock managed, phantoms), the corresponding production requirements are also available on the monitor, both the totals and the detail list.

Figure 13: Output List of the Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP tool with requirements details

 

The monitor has two planning modes: the fix-photo mode and the real-time mode, similar to classic MRP List (static) and Stocks/Requirements List (dynamic). The default planning mode is executed by using the fix photo of the initial stock (“Planning Fix-Photo”). Using this mode, the entire requirements of the day and the entire receipts (purchase and manufacturing) are shown. The other mode is the online planning which uses the current available stock on real-time (“Planning Real-Time”). Using this other mode, only the pending requirements of the day and the pending purchase/manufacturing orders are shown.

Figure 14: Output List of the Monitor for the different Planning Modes.

Figure 15: Output List with Details for the different Planning Modes.

 

The monitor can display the quantities on any unit of measure available in the materials. The monitor allows to select the base unit of measure of the material, the kilograms or an alternative unit of measure to be entered by the user. This can be done either on the selection screen or directly on the main screen, as well as the planning mode.

Figure 16: Output List of the Monitor showing quantities in different units of measure.

 

Finally, the Monitor can display the total percentage of loss of the materials as scrap, like standard SAP, but also as drop or yield. This is just a percentage related to food processing loss, but very relevant for the planner when taking purchase decisions during the evaluation process.

Figure 17: Output List of the Monitor showing total percentage of loss by different ways.

 

Action Buttons for Purchasing Planning Monitor MRP

The Monitor has an action button to create a new purchase order. Furthermore, on the different screens with the details list of receipts, when clicking on the purchase or production order, the monitor navigates to the corresponding maintenance application, where the user can directly edit the date and/or the quantity. This considerably improves the number of clicks required to perform those actions compared to use new modes.

 

Figure 18: Output List of the Monitor with the action button “Create New Purchase Order”.

 

Helpful Links

Materials Requirements Planning (SAP Help Portal)

Evaluating the Planning Run (SAP Help Portal)

 

[Disclaimer: Written by Juan Ventura (LinkedIn). This blog post is written by the author based on his personal experience while working on customers with SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud. Opinions and views expressed herein are solely my own. Before implementing any solution, you are advised to always do the analysis and adopt a solution for specific business case only if it suits customer requirements and testing is successful.]

entry.title: Re: GM budget values do not enter ledger 9K as consumed a...
entry.content:
Hello,

I know it’s a bit late, but I thought I would answer the question here to help others who may face the same issue.

The problem occurs because the data source for defining consumed amounts is set to GMUP – GM PB Commitment/Actual Data instead of GMBP – GM Payment Budget in the “Adjust Ledger for User-Specific Availability Control” customization point.

This setting is typically used if you have user-defined AVC ledgers (besides 9K, the standard AVC ledgers provided by SAP) and you want to perform specific budget consistency checks.

a. If this is not your case, you can skip the configuration point “Define Budget Values as Consumed Amounts.”
b. If you do need to add entries here, then you must first change the data source in “Adjust Ledger for User-Specific Availability Control” from GMUP to GMBP.

Important: Before doing this, deactivate ledger 9K in the customization point “Maintain Activation Status for GM Availability Control Ledger.”

After deactivating ledger 9K:

  1. Change the data source from GMUP to GMBP.

  2. Add the required entries in “Define Budget Values as Consumed Amounts.”

  3. Reactivate ledger 9K in “Maintain Activation Status for GM Availability Control Ledger.”

I hope this helps!

Best regards,
Luis

entry.title: unable to remove postgreSQL,hyperscaler option on SAP BTP entitlements
entry.content:
We were unable to save your changes for PostgreSQL, Hyperscaler Option - trial.

If you are trying to decrease or remove a quota, make sure that this quota is not in use.

If the problem persists, please post a question to SAP Community for assistance.

Reason: Failed to update quota in remote provisioning due to: The requested quota amount change [0] is lower than the currently consumed quota [1]. The requested quota amount change cannot be lower than the consumed quota

entry.title: Insert and List Data via Google BigQuery Adapter for SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
For Big Data enthusiasts, Google BigQuery is one of the most powerful and easy to access data warehouse offerings available on cloud.  It's scalability and analytical capabilities also make it the preferred choice for businesses who want to use store historical data and use it to derive insights.

A great product for leveraging these features in your integration scenarios is Google BigQuery Adapter for SAP Integration Suite. This blog explores a scenario for data insertion and listing for a table.

How to Insert and List data Google BigQuery Tables

BigQuery uses columnar data storage, it is cloud based and serverless, meaning you don’t need to install any software before you can use it. Let us see how to insert and list data for tables in Google BigQuery Adapter.

Create Table via Postman

You can utilize the below code snippet to create the table in Google BigQuery.

{
  "tableReference": {
    "tableId": "data"
  },
  "schema": {
    "fields": [
      {
        "name": "Name",
        "type": "STRING",
        "mode": "NULLABLE"
      },
      {
        "name": "ID",
        "type": "INTEGER",
        "mode": "NULLABLE"
      },
      {
        "name": "Variable",
        "type": "FLOAT",
        "mode": "NULLABLE"
      },
      {
        "name": "Secret_Code",
        "type": "BYTES",
        "mode": "NULLABLE"
      },
      {
        "name": "Is_Permanent",
        "type": "BOOLEAN",
        "mode": "NULLABLE"
      },
      {
        "name": "joining_date",
        "type": "DATE",
        "mode": "NULLABLE"
      },
      {
        "name": "latest_timestamp",
        "type": "DATETIME",
        "mode": "NULLABLE"
      },
      {
        "name": "timestamp",
        "type": "INTEGER",
        "mode": "NULLABLE"
      },
      {
        "name": "time",
        "type": "TIME",
        "mode": "NULLABLE"
      },
      {
        "name": "location",
        "type": "GEOGRAPHY",
        "mode": "NULLABLE"
      },
      {
        "name": "Variable1",
        "type": "NUMERIC",
        "mode": "NULLABLE"
      },
      {
        "name": "Variable2",
        "type": "BIGNUMERIC",
        "mode": "NULLABLE"
      },
      {
        "name": "additional",
        "type": "RECORD",
        "mode": "NULLABLE",
        "fields": [
          {
            "name": "sub_field1",
            "type": "STRING",
            "mode": "NULLABLE"
          },
          {
            "name": "sub_field2",
            "type": "STRING",
            "mode": "NULLABLE"
          }
        ]
      },
      {
        "name": "misc",
        "type": "RECORD",
        "mode": "NULLABLE",
        "fields": [
          {
            "name": "sub_field1",
            "type": "STRING",
            "mode": "NULLABLE"
          },
          {
            "name": "sub_field2",
            "type": "STRING",
            "mode": "NULLABLE"
          }
        ]
      }
    ]
  }
}

Prepare the Insert Payload 

Let us assume you need to insert data for two employees: data consisting of various data types and multiple values in a single record.  Go through the below payload to explore the different fields.

{
  "rows": [
    {
      "json": {
        "Name": "John Doe",
        "ID": 123,
        "Variable": 45.67,
        "Secret_Code": "U29tZSBieXRlcyBkYXRh", 
        "Is_Permanent": true,
        "joining_date": "2024-03-11",
        "latest_timestamp": "2024-03-11T14:30:00",
        "timestamp": "1709802600",
        "time": "14:30:00",
        "location": "POINT(-73.935242 40.730610)",
        "Variable1": "12345.678901234",
        "Variable2": "98765432101234567890.123456789012345678901234567890",
        "additional": {
          "sub_field1": "Blood",
          "sub_field2": "A+"
        },
        "misc": {
          "sub_field1": "Code",
          "sub_field2": "CRE"
        }
      }
    },
    {
      "json": {
        "Name": "Barry Allen",
        "ID": 456,
        "Variable": 98.76,
        "Secret_Code": "QW5vdGhlciBieXRlcyBkYXRh",
        "Is_Permanent": false,
        "joining date": "2024-03-12",
        "latest_timestamp": "2024-03-12T16:45:00",
        "timestamp": "1709889000",
        "time": "16:45:00",
        "location": "POLYGON((-73.935242 40.730610, -73.935242 40.731610, -73.934242 40.731610, -73.934242 40.730610, -73.935242 40.730610))",
        "Variable1": "98765.432109876",
        "Variable2": "12345678901234567890.987654321098765432109876543210",
        "additional": {
          "sub_field1": "Blood",
          "sub_field2": "A+"
        },
        "misc": {
          "sub_field1": "Code",
          "sub_field2": "CRE"
        }
      }
    }
  ]
}

Connect to Google BigQuery

The Connection tab contains connection and authentication parameters that need to be populated to establish connection with Google BigQuery.

Configuration for Insert and List

This is a very straightforward configuration which requires you to select Table Data as entity and InsertAll operation.

Now you must specify your Google Project ID, followed by Dataset ID and Table ID for your target table.

For List operation, the configuration requires the same parameters as before in Dataset ID and Table ID. However, to customize our response and save costs we use Query Parameters and Max Results to limit our search results.

For more information on how to use this operation using query parameters  see https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/reference/rest/v2/tabledata/list

Verify Data and Search Results

Finally, you can log in to Google console to view the table with data. 

You can also validate the List operation results via CPI.

 

If you’re interested in learning more about the Google Big Query Adapter, do check out the announcement blog by SAP for Google BigQuery Adapter for SAP Integration Suite.

Happy Learning !

entry.title: Re: Extra line items with zero value in settlement document
entry.content: Definitely, the root cause is with your variant characteristics. In your Condition Contract via WCOCO, check how variant characteristics are assigned. Ensure only the relevant combinations are used in the accrual logic

entry.title: SAP Build Work Zone Security
entry.content:
I've been spending quite some time recently diving deep into SAP Build Work Zone security, and let me tell you, it's a journey. Terms like #IAS, #BTP Subaccount #trusts, and #ShadowUsers can sometimes feel like a maze.

But then, an analogy clicked for me - the #DigitalMall and suddenly, the whole complex architecture started making perfect sense. I wanted to share this breakdown with all of you, hoping it helps.

Let's imagine SAP Build Work Zone as a bustling, modern Digital Mall, where users (you, the #shoppers) come to access various #stores (business applications) and "services" (collaboration features). Every security layer has a purpose, just like every part of a well run mall

#TheGrandOpening: Understanding this Digital Mall's Foundation

Before anyone even walks in, the mall has a master plan and a way to organize its offerings:

>>> SAP BTP Subaccount: Think of this as the Mall's Main Entrance & Security Gate. It's the primary gateway, controlling who can even step foot inside your digital space. It's where core permissions are managed.

>>> SAP Build Work Zone Tenant: This is your specific, unique instance of the Mall itself - your personalized shopping experience!

>>> #ContentManager: This acts like the Mall's Central Directory or Information Kiosk. It lists all the "stores" (your business applications) available within the mall, helping shoppers find what they need

>>> Content Providers: These are the "Department Stores" (like SAP S/4HANA
SuccessFactors) or even smaller "Boutiques" (your custom applications). They reside outside your immediate mall structure but integrate seamlessly, making their offerings available inside your Work Zone.

>>>>Stepping Inside: Your Identity & Basic Mall Access<<<<

Now, for the really crucial part: how does a "shopper" (your user) actually get into the Digital Mall, and how is their identity validated at the main entrance?

>>> #SAPCloudIdentityServices - Identity Authentication (IAS): The Mall's Central Security System / ID Proxy

This is the mandatory first stop for any user trying to enter your Work Zone mall. #IAS is your primary #IdentityProvider [IDP]

>>> #Proxy Mode: If your organization uses its own Corporate IdP (like Azure AD, Okta), IAS acts as a clever proxy. You authenticate against your corporate system, and IAS then receives that verified identity, federating it onward in a way Work Zone understands. It's seamless, you just show your corporate ID.

>>> #TheDigitalIdCard (SAML Assertion / OIDC Token): Once authenticated, IAS issues a secure token. This token is packed with vital information, essentially your digital "ID Card" that gets you past the main gate:

>>> #SubjectNameIdentifier (SNI): This is your main identifier (e.g., your Login Name or Employee ID). It's what the BTP Subaccount primarily uses.

#Assertion Attribute (often IAS UUID): This is a unique, stable, and persistent ID assigned by IAS. It's super important for internal Work Zone component communication later on, especially with the DWS (our "Community Center," which I'll cover in Part 2!)

---> Other standard user attributes like email, first name, last name.

SAP BTP Subaccount Trust Configuration: The Main Gate's Agreement with IAS

Your BTP Subaccount (the main gate) has a "trust agreement" with IAS. This allows it to confidently accept those digital ID cards (tokens) from IAS.

>>> #The XSUAA Shadow User: Your Mall Access Card. This is one of the most critical concepts

When a user successfully authenticates via IAS for the first time, a "Shadow User" record is either created or identified in the BTP Subaccount's internal user list. Think of this as your personal "Mall Access Card" record.

 

Why is it needed? Even if IAS knows who you are, the BTP Subaccount needs its own local record (the shadow user) to attach BTP Role Collections to it. These role collections are your "Mall-wide Privileges" (e.g., WorkZone_User, WorkZone_Admin) that determine what you can do across the whole Work Zone platform.

 

>>>> Crucial Point: If a shadow user doesn't exist (and automatic creation isn't enabled), login to Work Zone will fail because there is no local identity to attach permissions to.

Principal Propagation: Seamless Access to Department Stores!

Once you're in the mall and launch an app from an On-Premise Backend System (like an S/4HANA Fiori app via SAP Cloud Connector), you don't want to log in again, right?

This is where ##Principal Propagation comes in! Your identity (using the IAS SNI from the BTP trust) is seamlessly passed through the BTP Destination Service and SAP Cloud Connector directly to the backend system. The S/ 4HANA system then recognizes you and authorizes your access based on your roles within S/4HANA. It's like your Mall Access Card automatically opening the staff-only doors in a department store.

This is just the exciting first step of understanding Work Zone security. In Part 2, coming next.

The Digital Workplace Service (DWS) (the Mall's Community Center).

User and User List Provisioning (how the Community Center gets its member lists).

The critical differences between Internal vs. External Users (different types of Community Center members).

And how SCIM APIs are the "automated delivery trucks" for all this data!

Stay tuned for more insights, and in the meantime, I'd love to hear your thoughts or questions on this first part in the comments below!

Happy Work Zone-ing!

Lets connect and learn together ✌️

entry.title: Re: Side by Side extension APPlication
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question. I'm very sorry for the late response.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves the issue?

It seems like you are encountering an authentication issue when trying to access your portal/workzone subscription site. This issue might be related to the configuration of identity providers and the integration between SAP BTP and SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Possible Solutions

  1. Identity Provider Configuration:

    • Ensure that the SAP BTP subaccount is correctly configured to use the IAS of the S/4HANA Cloud. This involves setting up trust and federation with identity providers. You can refer to the documentation on Trust and Federation with Identity Providers Configuration of Integrated SAP BTP Apps for detailed steps.

  2. Communication Arrangements:

    • Verify that the communication arrangements are correctly set up in the S/4HANA Cloud. This includes ensuring that the correct user credentials are used and that the destination service is properly configured.

  3. Error Handling:

    • If you are seeing specific error messages, such as ‘Refused to connect’ or ‘unexpected AuthnResponse’, these might be related to domain allowlisting or multiple identity providers being enabled. Check the Configuration of Integrated SAP BTP Apps for troubleshooting steps.

  4. Session Management:

    • Consider configuring automatic sign-out settings to ensure that sessions are managed correctly across integrated applications. This can help prevent authentication errors related to session timeouts.

  5. Technical User Setup:

    • Ensure that the technical user for CPI is correctly set up with the necessary roles and permissions. If you are using a custom IAS, make sure that the technical user is configured to authenticate against it. You can find more information on setting up a technical user in the Technical User CPI with Custom IAS Technical user CPI with custom IAS blog.
[1] Configuration of Integrated SAP BTP Apps
[2] Technical user CPI with custom IAS
Kind regards, 
Henrike

entry.title: A GitHub action to update tenant subscriptions for multitenant SaaS applications on BTP
entry.content:
Introduction

When deploying a multitenant SaaS app on BTP using GitHub Actions, you may want to update tenant subscriptions after each successful deployment. While there are a couple of ways to approach this, they either require manual implementation, or they only solve the problem partially.

One obvious approach is to run cds-mtx upgrade as part of your deployment workflow. However, this only updates the database schemas and does not handle all tenant dependencies.

Another option is to call the SaaS Provisioning Service APIs directly. While this works, it requires you to roll your own implementation which might be a bit too much effort.

A custom GitHub action

To simplify this process, I created a reusable GitHub Action that automatically updates all tenant dependencies by leveraging the SaaS Provisioning Service APIs. You can find it here:

https://github.com/gbrfarkas/btp-saas-sub-update-action

The action can be integrated into your deployment workflow and provides clear status updates and error reporting directly in the pipeline output.

Here’s an example of how to use it:

uses: gbrfarkas/btp-saas-sub-update-action@v1
with:
  api-url: 'https://saas-manager.cfapps.<region>.hana.ondemand.com'
  token-url: 'https://<...>.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token'
  client-id: '...'
  client-secret: '...'
  timeout: 180
  interval: 10

To configure it, you’ll need to provide:

  • The API endpoint and token URL for your SaaS Provisioning Service instance

  • Credentials (client ID and client secret)

  • Optional values for timeout and check interval (to control how often the action checks progress during updates)

Summary

This custom GitHub action provides a simple way to update all tenant subscriptions and dependencies in a multitenant SaaS BTP app which you can easily integrate into your deployment pipeline.

Hopefully some of you find this useful to automate subscriptions updates. It's still a bit experimental so use it at your own risk in a productive environment.

entry.title: Fin de vida de Onboarding 1.0 en SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Fin de vida de Onboarding 1.0 en SAP SuccessFactors

SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding 1.0 llegará al fin de mantenimiento el 14 de mayo de 2026 y será eliminado con el lanzamiento productivo 1H 2026 en esa misma fecha.
Renovarte al nuevo Onboarding es la clave para mantener tu onboarding corporativo al día.

Fechas clave (sujetas a cambios)

Hito Fecha Descripción
End of Development21 de mayo de 2021SAP dejó de desarrollar mejoras; solo se corrigen errores críticos.
End of Maintenance14 de mayo de 2026Fin de parches, correcciones y nuevas funcionalidades.
Eliminación14 de mayo de 2026El módulo dejará de estar disponible para uso productivo.

Detalles de la transición

  • SAP anuncia el reemplazo de Onboarding 1.0 por la nueva solución Onboarding.

  • No existe una migración automática: se requiere una reimplementación completa.

  • SAP ofrece plantillas de configuración, herramientas de planificación y servicios de migración a través de partners certificados.

  • No necesitas adquirir una nueva licencia si ya cuentas con Onboarding 1.0.

Línea de tiempo resumida

  • Q4 2019: se lanzó el nuevo Onboarding; momento ideal para iniciar la transición.

  • 1H 2026: fin del mantenimiento de Onboarding 1.0.

  • 14 de mayo de 2026: Onboarding 1.0 deja de funcionar; asegúrate de haber completado la reimplementación.

💡 Recomendación clave: inicia hoy tu plan de reimplementación para evitar interrupciones en los procesos de onboarding. Asegura continuidad, cumplimiento y una transición sin contratiempos.

Referencias

  • SAP Help Portal: Replacement of Onboarding 1.0 with Onboarding

  • SAP Note 3344522: Onboarding 1.0 Transformation Resources and Deprecation Announcement

Hi Team,

We are trying to raise a request for a new vpn connection to our private cloud but the template (Set Up Hyperscaler VPN Connection (AWS/Azure/GCP) ) is not visible when creating service requests. I tried requesting through "Assisted Service Request" but I got the following reply:

"We cannot proceed with this Service Request as it is created using Assisted Service Request Template, where we already have a dedicated Service Template for this service. Requesting service through the wrong template may lead to unnecessary back-and-forth interactions, delayed activity start, quality issues, and downtime misses. So we request you to create a Service Request with template "Set Up Hyperscaler VPN Connection (AWS/Azure/GCP)" "

Please advise how can we raise the request, I have been trying for a long time now and this has affected our go-live.

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Set Up Hyperscaler VPN Connection (AWS/Azure/GCP) tem...
entry.content:
The reason why you are unable to raise request "Set Up Hyperscaler VPN Connection (AWS/Azure/GCP)" is because you don't have the necessary authorization to do so.

In order to submit a service request for the 'Set Up Hyperscaler VPN Connection (AWS/Azure/GCP)' template, an S-user must be authorized to Create Billable Service Requests at the customer number level.

Upon reviewing your S-user ID and your super administrator S-user, I found that the required authorization was only assigned at the installation level. Usually, you will need to contact your administrator listed in Users & Contacts - SAP for Me to have the authorization assigned. As your super administrator lacks the necessary authorization, I have manually updated the permissions for both S-user IDs to ensure that the required authorization is now assigned at the customer number level. Please clear your browser cache and attempt to submit the request again to verify that the issue has been resolved.

For more detailed information on S-user authorizations required the Private Cloud Service Request application, please refer to KBA 2669783 - S-user authorizations required for the Private Cloud Service Request application - SAP for Me 

If you encounter any further difficulties or require additional assistance, please do not hesitate to contact us.

Have a nice day!

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: SAP BTP now available on Microsoft Azure, AWS, and Google Cloud Marketplaces

At Sapphire Orlando 2025, we announced SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) availability through Hyperscaler Marketplaces.  I’m happy to share that SAP BTP services are now available for purchase through Microsoft Azure, Amazon Web Services (AWS), and Google Cloud Marketplaces in the United States. 

Why SAP BTP?   

SAP BTP is SAP’s platform for all SAP applications with over 33,000 customers, 3,000 partners, and 10,000 pre-built accelerators.  It empowers customers and partners with generative AI-powered development, automation, integration, data, and analytics across SAP and non-SAP applications, business processes, and beyond. Accelerate time to value with pre-built workflows and integrations across Finance, HR, Supply Chain, Procurement and more. Empower developers of all skills with tools and languages of their choice, and purpose-built frameworks for business application development. Leverage generative AI capabilities specialized in automating and extending mission-critical business processes.

 

 Here are the key benefits for purchasing SAP BTP through Hyperscaler Marketplaces: 

1. Maximize Cost Efficiency with Existing Cloud Commitments 

Existing customers of Microsoft Azure, AWS, and Google Cloud can use their committed spend agreements to purchase SAP BTP through their respective cloud marketplaces. The ability to channel unused commitments toward SAP BTP investments allows customers to optimize their budgets and drive more value from their relationships with the Hyperscaler providers. Customers gain greater financial flexibility and can ensure that every dollar spent accelerates their digital transformation initiatives. 

2. Accelerated Procurement and Deployment 

Existing customers are familiar with the purchasing process through their Microsoft Azure, AWS, and Google Cloud hyperscaler marketplaces, making it easy for them to discover, select, and purchase SAP BTP services in one centralized platform. SAP BTP can then be deployed directly on hyperscaler infrastructure that customers already have in place and rely on for scalability, security, and innovation. This process allows for accelerated procurement and deployment, meaning customers can start innovating with SAP BTP services faster than ever!   

3. Simplified Billing and Vendor Consolidation 

Through Microsoft Azure, AWS, and Google Cloud Marketplaces, customers receive consolidated billing and invoicing that allows them to manage all their hyperscaler cloud services in one place. This enables customers to have better visibility into their spend management, streamline administrative tasks, and ensure compliance with corporate procurement policies. It also reduces the complexity of managing different vendors. 

 

Get Started Today 

Customers in the Uinted States (US) now have the ability to purchase SAP BTP through the hyperscaler marketplaces and the flexibility to run SAP BTP services in their hyperscaler of choice. This reflects SAP’s vision for openness and flexibility and gives our customers the ability to integrate, extend, and innovate their SAP and non-SAP applications.   

To begin your SAP BTP journey, visit the Microsoft Azure, Amazon Web Services, or Google Cloud marketplaces for more information or get in touch with your SAP BTP specialist.  Whether you're looking to move, optimize, or innovate your SAP applications, or create new AI and data-driven experiences, we are ready to help you accelerate your transformation with SAP BTP!

entry.title: Getting Ready for AI-Assisted Applicant Screening in SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Getting Ready for AI-Assisted Applicant Screening in SAP SuccessFactors

Recruiting is one of the most time-consuming parts of HR. For many companies, every new job role attracts hundreds of CVs. Recruiters spend hours reading applications, hiring managers get frustrated waiting for shortlists, and candidates often feel lost in the process.

SAP SuccessFactors has introduced a new feature — AI-assisted applicant screening, powered by Joule — to make this easier. The idea is simple: the system can read applications, match skills to the job, and even rank candidates from best to least fit. This has the potential to change how recruiters work, but there is something important to understand.

This feature does not simply work out of the box. To get value from it, you first need to set up some important building blocks in your system.

What you need before enabling AI-assisted screening

Over the last few months of working with clients, I have seen that the success of AI-assisted screening depends on six key areas:

1. Recruiting Management (RCM)

This is the foundation. Without properly structured job requisitions, application templates, and candidate profiles, there is no data for AI to work on.

2. Job Profile Builder (JPB)

Job Profile Builder is where you define jobs, roles, competencies, and required skills. The better this is set up, the stronger the AI matching will be. Think of it as the dictionary that AI uses to understand your jobs.

3. Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH)

This is becoming more and more important. TIH provides a single skills framework across the system. When jobs and candidates speak the same “skills language,” the AI can make much better decisions about fit and ranking.

4. Joule with AI Units License

Joule is the intelligence layer inside SAP SuccessFactors. With the AI Units license, Joule can power features such as skills extraction, candidate-job matching, stack ranking, and even generating interview questions. Without Joule and the license, the feature cannot be enabled.

5. Role-Based Permissions (RBP)

Permissions are often overlooked. Recruiters and hiring managers need access to view AI insights, while system administrators need access to configure and monitor AI services.

6. Clean and consistent data

The simplest, but often the hardest step. If job descriptions are vague, or candidate data is incomplete, the AI will not give useful results. Clean data is the backbone of any successful AI implementation.

Why stack ranking makes a difference

The most useful feature of AI-assisted screening is stack ranking. This means applicants are automatically sorted from best fit to least fit based on the job requirements and the skills framework.

This helps in many ways:

  • Recruiters save time by not manually scanning hundreds of CVs.

  • Hiring managers get a clear shortlist and understand why certain candidates are ranked higher.

  • Every applicant is checked in the same way, which makes the process more consistent and fair.

  • Recruiters get more time to focus on meaningful conversations with candidates instead of repetitive screening tasks.

A real example from practice

One global technology company I worked with introduced AI-assisted screening for their campus hiring. They received thousands of applications for a single drive. Normally, this would take recruiters several weeks to manage.

With stack ranking enabled, the system automatically highlighted the most relevant candidates. The results:

  • Screening time reduced by 40 percent

  • Recruiters could finally spend more time engaging with students

  • Hiring managers felt the shortlist was of much higher quality

The company is now planning to extend this approach to experienced hiring as well.

Final thoughts

AI-assisted applicant screening in SAP SuccessFactors is not about replacing recruiters. It is about helping them focus on people, not paperwork.

But success depends on getting the basics right. Recruiting Management, Job Profile Builder, Talent Intelligence Hub, Joule with AI Units, Role-Based Permissions, and clean data — these are the real prerequisites.

Once these are in place, stack ranking can truly change the way hiring teams work — making recruitment faster, fairer, and more consistent.

entry.title: Use of quartile position in SuccessFactors compensation for Compensation Planning
entry.content:
Scenario:

In today’s competitive job market, ensuring fair and strategic pay decisions is more crucial than ever. Hence organizations across industries are leaning into pay position driven frameworks to guide their compensation planning. Where Quartile positions can be used as an effective method and insightful feature.

What Are Quartiles in Compensation?

Imagine a salary range divided into four- five equal parts:

  • Minimum (Payrange Min/ Q1)
  • Lower Quartile (Q2)
  • Midpoint (Payrange Mid/Q3)
  • Upper Quartile (Q4)
  • Maximum (Payrange Max)

Each employee's salary can be mapped onto these quartiles and ranges, helping HR teams and compensation planners identify where an individual stands within the overall pay structure.

Interpreting the Quartile Breakdown to identify in which category employees falls:

Quartile

Salary Position

Implication

Q1 (0–25%)

Low Quartile

May deserve a larger merit adjustment

Q2–Q3 (25–75%)

Fairly Paid

Standard merit increases or bonus planning

Q4 (75–100%)

Highly Paid

Could receive lower merit increases

 The approach on how the Q1, Q2, Q3 and Q4 derives may vary from company to company.

🎯 Why Does It Matter?

Understanding salary positioning helps answer key questions in the compensation planning process:

  • Is this employee paid lesser compared to peers?
  • Should this high-performing employee get a bigger merit increase?
  • Payrange could be a way to get one more step closer to pay equity

It also guides promotion decisions and budget planning, ensuring pay increases are targeted where they’re needed most.

How to use SF functionality to meet the Organizations need:

entry.title: Restrict Access of OAuth2.0 Clients with the Technical User purpose
entry.content:
Hi,

New updates keep arrive our way, let's review one of the latest and compare with the previous situation.  The feature I'm talking about is the new purpose for OAuth2.0 Clients, named the 'Technical user'. 

 

 

What's new about it?

The Technical User purpose allows you to create OAuth 2.0 clients that can be linked to all scoped roles within your SAP Datasphere tenant. This includes:

  • General roles at the tenant level
  • and/or Roles at the space level

By leveraging this setup, you can enforce granular access restrictions. This means you can precisely control what the technical user can access, ensuring compliance with security and governance requirements.

Let's compare the purposes side-by-side


Interactive UsageFor human users who log in interactively via OAuth. Requires re-authorization based on Refresh Token Lifetime. - Logging into the Command Line Interface (CLI)
- Consuming data via OData API		 
API AccessFor programmatic access to APIs, typically for integrations.- Using SCIM 2.0 API for user provisioning
- Transporting content via Cloud Transport Management
- Exporting logs (audit activities)
- Connecting SAP Signavio		Limited to API-level permissions (tenant wide however)
Technical UserFor system-to-system communication or automation without user interaction.- Same as API Access but with broader flexibility
- Can include tenant-level and space-level roles
- Ideal for background jobs, ETL processes, and automation		Can be linked to all scoped roles (tenant + space)

 

 

In short we can conclude the following:

  • Interactive Usage: Used for CLI & OData API's. Provide the client parameters to users who need to connect clients, tools, or apps to SAP Datasphere
  • API Access: Designed for API calls (SCIM 2.0 API's, transporting content) but role assignment is limited.
  • Technical User: Same as API Access  but offers full role assignment flexibility, making it the most powerful for automation and service accounts.

You can read how to use OAuth2.0 Clients to Authenticate against SAP Datasphere for yourself here:  https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_DATASPHERE/9f804b8efa8043539289f42f372c4862/3f92b46fe0314e8ba60720e409c219fc.html. And thanks for reading the blog! Hope you share your own experience with the purposes in the comment section.

Kind Regards, Thibault

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4 Migration
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question. I'm very sorry for the late response.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves the issue?

Running parallel S/4 migration projects can significantly impact SAP landscapes and processes. Here are some insights into how this can be managed effectively:

Impact on SAP Landscapes

  1. Three-System Landscape (3SL):

    • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition provides a 3-system landscape consisting of development, test, and production systems. This setup is crucial for managing parallel projects as it allows for separate environments for development and testing before changes are moved to production.
    • The introduction of Parallel Project Line (PPL) enhances the implementation experience by providing additional customizing and testing environments, allowing separation of subsequent implementation projects from continuous innovations in the existing productive environment.

  2. Transport Management:

    • Managing transport requests efficiently is vital. SAP provides tools like the Transport Organizer in Eclipse-based ABAP Development Tools and various SAP Fiori apps for managing and importing transport requests.
    • It’s important to manage developments and transports in milestones or tacts to ensure consistency and avoid errors due to wrong transport sequences.

Process Alignment and Retrofit

  1. SAP Cloud ALM:

    • SAP Cloud ALM can be used to manage the complexity of multiple open transports and ensure alignment across projects. It provides features for managing requirements, documentation, testing, and related transports.
    • The Feature Management application in SAP Cloud ALM helps keep an overview of transports or collection versions that belong together.

  2. Digital Discovery Assessment (DDA):

    • The DDA app helps in scoping the legal contract and setting business priorities for the implementation project. It provides an interactive discovery workflow to refine where S/4HANA fits in the business.
    • SAP Cloud ALM can import the DDA Excel report to automatically create a project, helping define phases, sprints, and milestones.

N+2 Scenario

In an N+2 scenario, where multiple projects are running in parallel, it is crucial to ensure that changes in one project do not negatively impact others. This requires:

  • Regular Synchronization: Regularly synchronize changes across projects to ensure alignment.
  • Dependency Management: Use dependency checks to prevent errors due to wrong transport sequences.
  • Testing: Conduct thorough testing in separate environments to ensure changes are compatible across projects.

By leveraging tools like SAP Cloud ALM and managing transport requests effectively, organizations can successfully run parallel S/4 migration projects while maintaining alignment and ensuring smooth retrofitting.

 

[1] Transport Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
[2] Transitioning from an SAP ERP - S/4HANA On-Premise Practitioner to an SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Practitioner
[3] Leverage presales discussions to start your S/4 Implementation with Cloud
 
Kind regards,
Henrike

entry.title: Re: 关于月度结算请求处理
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question. I'm very sorry for the late response.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves the issue?

To automate the monthly closing of projects only for the current month, you need to ensure that the system processes only the items relevant to the current month and not future months. Here are some steps you can follow:

  1. Review Billing Dates: Ensure that the billing dates are correctly set for each transaction. For example, if a billing date is set for May 21, it should be processed in June, not May.

  2. Configure Settlement Jobs: When setting up the job for monthly closing, make sure to specify the correct parameters that limit the processing to the current month. This might involve setting the job to recognize only transactions with billing dates within the current month.

  3. Use Correct Input Parameters: In the job setup, use ‘period-end date’ as the input parameter instead of ‘as on date’. 3325419 - Failed to provide correct date for Job Template ‘Production Settlement in Parallel Ledgers’ or ; ‘Actual Settlement for Production Orders/Process Orders & Product Cost Collectors’ This ensures that only transactions up to the end of the current period are processed.

  4. Check System Settings: Verify that the system settings are configured to handle monthly closings correctly. This includes checking any flags or options that might affect how transactions are processed.

  5. Test the Configuration: Before fully implementing the job, run tests to ensure that it processes only the current month’s transactions and does not inadvertently include future transactions.

By following these steps, you can ensure that your monthly closing request processing job handles only the current month’s transactions, avoiding issues with future transactions being processed prematurely.

[1] 3325419 - Failed to provide correct date for Job Template 'Production Settlement in Parallel Ledgers' or ; 'Actual Settlement for Production Orders/Process Orders & Product Cost Collectors'

Kind regards, Henrike

entry.title: PM order attachments downloads from SAP Business Document Service - BDS
entry.content:
We develop simple program that enables the download of attachments linked to PM (Plant Maintenance) orders from the SAP Business Document Service (BDS). It confirms the PM order data from AUFK, determines attachment relationships via BDS connection tables, and exports the attached files (e.g., PDFs, JPGs, DOCs) to a specified local directory in a readable format. This tool enables download of multiple attachments per order and ensures that users can access and store PM-related documentation outside of SAP for reporting, analysis.
Take a note that this program does not provide download of attachments if they are saved in Generic Object Services. You can check you BDS tables: BDS_CON00 | CLASSNAME: 'BUS2007' -> OBJECT_KEY (PM order), OBJECT_KEY -> LOIO_ID, stored documents in final BDS_CONT1 table for confirmation of BDS use.

Code base of our solution:

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report ypm_download_pm_attachments
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*&
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
REPORT ypm_download_pm_attachments.

TABLES: aufk.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* SELECTION SCREEN
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF BLOCK b1 WITH FRAME TITLE TEXT-001.
*  PARAMETERS: p_aufnr TYPE aufk-aufnr OBLIGATORY, "PM Order Number
  SELECT-OPTIONS s_aufnr FOR aufk-aufnr NO INTERVALS.

  PARAMETERS:  p_path  TYPE string     OBLIGATORY. "Local Folder Path
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF BLOCK b1.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* EVENTS
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
AT SELECTION-SCREEN ON VALUE-REQUEST FOR p_path.
  " Provide F4 help to browse for a local directory
  cl_gui_frontend_services=>directory_browse(
    EXPORTING
      window_title    = 'Select a Folder'
      initial_folder  = 'C:\'
    CHANGING
      selected_folder = p_path
    EXCEPTIONS
      cntl_error      = 1
      OTHERS          = 2
  ).
  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    MESSAGE 'Could not open directory browser.' TYPE 'E'.
  ENDIF.

START-OF-SELECTION.
  " Data declarations
  DATA: lv_object_key TYPE bds_typeid,
        lv_class_name TYPE bds_clsnam VALUE 'BUS2007', " Business Object for PM Order
        lv_class_type TYPE bds_clstyp VALUE 'BO',      " Class Type for Business Object
        lv_full_path  TYPE string,
        lv_counter    TYPE i VALUE 0.

  " This internal table will receive ALL document data and properties
  DATA: lt_documents TYPE TABLE OF bapicompon.
  DATA: lt_signatures TYPE TABLE OF bapisignat.
  DATA: lt_content TYPE TABLE OF bapiconten.
  DATA: ls_content LIKE LINE OF lt_content.
  "This internal table will be used to fetch individual document content
  DATA: lt_signatures_docs TYPE TABLE OF bapisignat.
  DATA: lt_components_docs TYPE TABLE OF bapicompon.
  DATA: ls_sig LIKE LINE OF lt_signatures.

  LOOP AT s_aufnr INTO DATA(lr_aufnr). ""PM order number loop

    "Validate PM Order existence
    SELECT SINGLE aufnr FROM aufk
      INTO @DATA(lv_aufnr)
      WHERE aufnr = @LR_aufnr-low.

    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      WRITE: / |Order '{ lr_aufnr-low }' not found in table AUFK.|.
    ENDIF.

    lv_object_key = lv_aufnr.

    "Get ALL attachments and their data in a SINGLE call
    REFRESH: lt_signatures, lt_documents, lt_content.
    CALL FUNCTION 'BDS_BUSINESSDOCUMENT_GET_TAB'
      EXPORTING
        classname     = lv_class_name
        classtype     = lv_class_type
        object_key    = lv_object_key
      TABLES
        signature     = lt_signatures
        components    = lt_documents
        content       = lt_content
      EXCEPTIONS
        nothing_found = 1
        OTHERS        = 2.

    IF sy-subrc <> 0 OR lt_documents IS INITIAL.
      WRITE: / |No attachments found for PM Order '{ lv_aufnr }'.|.
    ENDIF.
    WRITE: /.
    WRITE: / |Downloading attachments for PM Order: { lv_aufnr }|.
    ULINE.

    DATA: ls_doc TYPE bapicompon.

    "Loop through the returned documents table
    LOOP AT lt_documents INTO ls_doc. ""Documents loop

      REFRESH: lt_content, lt_signatures_docs, lt_components_docs.
      CLEAR: ls_sig.

      IF ls_doc-doc_count IS INITIAL.
        " Skip if there is no content in the document
        CONTINUE.
      ENDIF.

      AT NEW doc_count.

        " Clear previous content tables
        READ TABLE lt_signatures INTO ls_sig WITH KEY doc_count = ls_doc-doc_count.
        IF  sy-subrc = 0.

          CALL FUNCTION 'BDS_DOCUMENT_GET_TABLE'
            EXPORTING
*             CLIENT          = SY-MANDT
              doc_id          = ls_sig-doc_id
*             BINARY_FLAG     = 'X'
            TABLES
              signature       = lt_signatures_docs
              components      = lt_components_docs
              content         = lt_content
*             ASCII_CONTENT   =
            EXCEPTIONS
              nothing_found   = 1
              parameter_error = 2
              not_allowed     = 3
              error_kpro      = 4
              internal_error  = 5
              not_authorized  = 6
              OTHERS          = 7.
          IF sy-subrc <> 0.
*error
          ENDIF.

        ENDIF.

      ENDAT.

      " The filename is available directly in the  COMP_ID field.
      DATA(lv_file_name) = ls_doc-comp_id.

      " Full local path and trigger the download
      TRY.
          lv_full_path = p_path && '\' && lv_aufnr && '_' && lv_file_name.

          cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_download(
            EXPORTING
              filename                = lv_full_path
              filetype                = 'BIN' " Use binary mode for all file types
            CHANGING
              data_tab                = lt_content
            EXCEPTIONS
              file_write_error        = 1
              no_batch                = 2
              gui_refuse_filetransfer = 3
              invalid_type            = 4
              OTHERS                  = 5
          ).

          IF sy-subrc = 0.
            ADD 1 TO lv_counter.
            WRITE: / |SUCCESS: Downloaded '{ lv_file_name }'|.
          ELSE.
            WRITE: / |ERROR: Failed to download '{ lv_file_name }'. SY-SUBRC: { sy-subrc }|.
          ENDIF.

        CATCH cx_root.
          MESSAGE 'A front-end services error occurred. Check your SAP GUI installation and authorizations.' TYPE 'E'.
      ENDTRY.

    ENDLOOP. ""Documents loop
  ENDLOOP. ""PM order number loop

  ULINE.
  WRITE: / |Target Directory: { p_path }|.
  WRITE: / |Download complete. Total files downloaded: { lv_counter }|.


The program outputs all attachments into the selected folder, with the PM order number concatenated at the beginning of each file name.

For archiving purposes different approach should be considered in order to be able to run program in background and have some kind of mass monitoring for successful downloads and logs. However, for quick download of few PM order's attachments this program could suffice.
I hope this saves some time to someone.

To allocate incidental costs such as customs clearance fees, unloading charges, and warehousing fees to imported raw materials in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, you can follow these steps:

1. CBC Scope Items

For this process, you should consider the following scope items:

  • Procurement of Services (22Z): Blog Series: SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition – 0… - SAP Community This scope item covers the procurement process, including service procurement which can be used for incidental costs.
  • Direct Procurement with Inbound Delivery (2TX): Blog Series: SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition – 0… - SAP Community This scope item includes the inbound delivery process, which is relevant for handling imported goods.
  • Manual Transportation Planning (6W2): Blog Series: SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition – 0… - SAP Community This scope item is useful for planning transportation, which can include incidental costs.
  • Freight Settlement (6W4): Blog Series: SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition – 0… - SAP Community This scope item deals with the settlement of freight costs, which can be part of the incidental costs.

2. Applications (Apps)

The process of allocating incidental costs can be executed in the following apps:

  • Create Purchase Order: Use this app to create purchase orders for the imported raw materials and include incidental costs as service items.
  • Create Supplier Invoice: This app is used to record the supplier invoices for the incidental costs.
  • Post Goods Movement: Use this app to record the receipt of goods and allocate costs to the inventory.

These steps will help ensure that incidental costs are properly allocated to the respective purchased raw materials, impacting inventory valuation and financial reporting.

Kind regards, Henrike

entry.title: Re: 我需要一个产品的最早入库过账日期和最新出库的过账日期的CDS,用于与和其他的CDS做拼接
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question. I'm very sorry for the late response.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves the issue?

To find the earliest inbound posting date and the latest outbound posting date for a product using CDS views, you can follow these steps:

Steps to Create CDS Views

  1. Identify Relevant CDS Views:

    • Use the View Browser app to search for CDS views that contain the fields you need. For inbound and outbound posting dates, you might consider using I_MaterialDocumentItem_2 which contains fields related to material documents and posting dates.

  2. Create a Custom CDS View:

    • Open the Custom CDS Views app.
    • Select I_MaterialDocumentItem_2 as your primary data source.
    • Add necessary fields such as Material, Plant, Posting Date, and any other relevant fields.
    • Use filters or calculations to determine the earliest and latest posting dates.

  3. Join with Other CDS Views:

    • If you need additional fields like Warehouse, you can join your custom CDS view with other views that contain these fields.

  4. Publish and Test:

    • Once your CDS view is configured, publish it and test using tools like Postman or directly within SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Example Code

Here is a simple example of how you might define a view to get the earliest and latest posting dates:

DEFINE VIEW Z_ProductPostingDates AS SELECT FROM I_MaterialDocumentItem_2 [Comparison of Report Development in 3SL & 2SL in S...](https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blogs-by-sap/comparison-of-report-development-in-3sl-2sl-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public/ba-p/13578738)
{
  key Material,
  key Plant,
  MIN(PostingDate) AS EarliestInboundDate,
  MAX(PostingDate) AS LatestOutboundDate
}
WHERE GoodsMovementType IN ('101', '261')
GROUP BY Material, Plant

Additional Resources

  • You can refer to SAP’s documentation or community blogs for more detailed guidance and examples.

If you need further assistance or a video tutorial, you might want to check SAP’s official learning resources or community forums. Virtual Data Model and CDS Views - Material Stock at Posting Date

[1] Comparison of Report Development in 3SL & 2SL in S...
[2] Virtual Data Model and CDS Views - Material Stock at Posting Date
Kind regards, Henrike

entry.title: Lean Services Enablement in Commercial Project Management
entry.content:
Introduction

Commercial Project Management (CPM) provides functions that address the core business process requirements of companies that offer project-based services to their customers. These functions cover multiple processes in an end-to-end scenario spanning the selling, planning, execution, monitoring, and controlling of projects. A core aspect of this process involves the various resource types for carrying out financial activities like Activity, Expense, Human Resource, Material and Revenue.

The SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0 release introduces Lean Services in CPM which can be used as a resource type for carrying out the financial activities. This extends the earlier introduction of Lean Service Components within Project System (PS) delivered in SAP S/4 HANA 2023 FPS1, providing a seamless experience across both CPM and PS. This blog outlines the essential configuration steps and system prerequisites for activating and integrating Lean Services in CPM, thereby enabling efficient handling of external procurement.

Types of Lean Services

  • Planned Lean Services: Services for which the quantity and exact value is known at the time of creating the purchase requisition.
  • Unplanned Lean Services: Services for which the exact value is not known at the time of creating the purchase requisition. Instead of a fixed price, you enter a value limit that must not be exceeded.

CPM now supports the integration of both Planned and Unplanned Lean Services. This functionality is enabled through the steps described below:

Prerequisite Configuration

  • Define the Resource Types for Lean Service in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Define Resource Types.Figure 1: Resource Types for Lean Services Enablement
  • Assign the resource types to the plan scenario for which financial plan will be done in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Link Plan Scenario to Resource Types.Figure 2: Link Plan Scenario to Resource Types for Lean Services Enablement

Integration with Project System (PS)

The following frameworks in CPM now support Lean Services integration with PS:

Import Planned data to CPM: In order to import data from objects in Project System (PS) into a financial plan, add the import method in IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Import Data -> Make Settings for Import Methods.

Figure 3: Import Methods for Lean Services Enablement

Add the Import Methods to Import Strategies in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Import Data -> Make Settings for Import Strategies.

Figure 4: Import Strategies for Lean Services Enablement

Transfer Planned data to PS: In order to transfer planned data such as quantities, cost, or revenue to business objects in backend systems, add the transfer method in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Transfer Data -> Make Settings for Transfer Methods.

Figure 5: Transfer Methods for Lean Services Enablement

Add the Transfer Methods to Transfer Strategies in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Transfer Data -> Make Settings for Transfer Strategies.

Figure 6: Transfer Strategies for Lean Services Enablement

Add the import and transfer strategies to the plan scenario in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Link Plan Scenario to Version Types.

Figure 7: Link Plan Scenario to Version Types for Lean Services Enablement

Once the above configuration steps are completed, you can seamlessly import the planned data for Lean Service Components from PS, carry out your planning and send the planned data back to PS - just like any other resource type. 

The following example illustrates an end-to-end scenario starting with planning of Lean Service Components in PS followed by importing the planned data into CPM. Planning activities are then carried out in CPM and the planned data is transferred back to PS.

Planning of Lean Service Components in PS

Figure 8: Planning of Planned Lean Service Components in PS

Figure 9: Planning of Unplanned Lean Service Components in PS

 Planned data of Lean Service Components imported from PS to CPM successfully

Figure 10: Import Planned Data of Lean Services from PS into CPM

Planning of Lean Services in CPM

Figure 11: Planning of Lean Services in CPM

Transfer of Planned data from CPM to PS

Figure 12: Transfer of Planned Data of Lean Services from CPM to PS

Planned data transferred from CPM to PS successfully

Figure 13: Transfer of Planned Data from CPM to PS for Planned Lean Service

 Figure 14: Transfer of Planned Data from CPM to PS for Unplanned Lean Service

Additional Information

For more details on Lean Services, you may refer below links:

  • Planning Lean Services
  • Lean Service Enablement for Project Networks
